question.title: Launch a java jar downloaded locally, as it if was run from a web browser?
question.body:
Is it possible to launch a local jar as if it was run directly from a web browser. Is there some way to pass the URL as a variable to it to make it think it was?

It seems that java jar's don't work properly if downloaded and run locally, rather than being run from the web browser. Is this just because one or a few variables (-D x=y) aren't set if run locally? Can this been worked-around? The error messages don't give me enough info to see where to start.

I have to deal with many old bits of enterprise gear where the web server doesn't use modern TLS/SSL ciphers, needs embedded java, or similar. I've had pretty good luck with keeping a couple old versions of Firefox installed in parallel, pointed to a couple old java versions, modifying security settings as needed, but I still run into some issues, and it would really help to be able to run locally with just java without needing an old browser.

If I try to run a JAR from the URL:

./j2sdk1.4.2_19/bin/java -jar 'https://192.168.1.4/main.jar'

Unable to access jarfile https://192.168.1.4/main.jar

If I try to run a downloaded JAR:

./j2sdk1.4.2_19/bin/java -jar main.jar

GUI: "Invalid server address"

question_comments.body: Unable to access jarfile 192.168.1.4/main.jar That's only going to work if you've set up a web server to serve the jnlp from that address.

You need to know that Java Web Start has been phased out, no longer a part of Java SE. See Oracle white paper, Java Client Roadmap Update of 2020-05. You may want to consider the open-source alternative, OpenWebStart.
Does your Question involve Applets or not? If not, your applet tag should be deleted.
Java 1.4.2 and 1.6 are terrible old and security nightmares. No one should be using them.
What's the error if the downloaded jar is run?

Java applets are deprecated since 2017, and browsers don't support them anymore. What are you trying to do? Why do you need to involve a browser? Just download the jar file and run it? You can pass whatever you want when you call the jar file? I guess I don't understand what you are asking. Can you edit the question and clarify?
